description:
I'm very proud to be in a city where Valentine's Day pillow fights with hundreds of strangers is a thing.

I went with my husband and I was afraid that it'd be awkward so we would end up hitting each other all night. Turns out people have no problem hitting random strangers in the face. 
It isn't SF if people aren't in costumes. But it's okay if that's too much effort, most people were just dressed casually. 

Tips:
Bring a doctor's mask and a CLEAN pillow. Nasty drool/sweat/vomit stained pillow owners were hit extra hard.
author: Tata X.

description: This is perfect for single people people in the bay, because its every pillow fighter for themselves kind of a thing. You dont even notice that you came alone/ brought a date its basically pure chaos O.o
author: Gina B.

description:
What better way to end a Valentines Day? This is an event that you have to go at least once in your lifetime. An epic pillow fight with around 1000+ random strangers? YES. This is the best place to take out your aggression in a healthy way using pillows to hit people and having the time of your life. The event is non-official and non-permitted so come at your own will. There was a website that stated the event starts at 6pm and that's pretty much when it started. Not sure if I would say this is a "good for children" event due to all the semi-violence. Although, there were kids and I got beat up by 3 kids with really hard pillows all at once! Kids can be really aggressive... Hahaha. 

Recommendation: wear a mask because I didn't and I was choking on feathers and cotton. Yuck. Maybe some fun costume! 

Knocking off one star because some people took this pillow fight too seriously. When it started dying down, there were 2 girls that were hitting each other with pillows and then their pillows turned into fists instead...yikes. I would say to leave earlier than near the end because things get kind of crazy. 

But other than that, just an event to have fun. Definitely an event to go to at least once! Bring your pillows!!
author: Tiffany H.

description:
WOW! Just WOW! 

There is nothing that I can say that would fully describe this event beside WOW! Not only is it a great way to spend time with your significant other, if you have one, but it is also a great way to relieve some built in stress and you just happen to have an extra pillow. Its wonderful how the city has such an amazing cool event because it just makes it a better city to visit or even live in. 

Some advice for first timers next year is to bring a face mask, that way you won't have a hard time breathing when there is a ton of feathers flying in your face. 

Overall, if you have no plans for Valentine's day then this is the place to be because who knows, you may even meet your significant other
author: Benson M.

description:
Pillows! Pillows everywhere!

This pillow fight club embodies San Francisco perfectly. Only the city by the Bay could come up with the idea of whacking each other with pillows while naked men smoke weed nearby. Good times!

But yeah, it's a lot of fun. Hundreds of people joined in, and there was tons of fluff around. I'd say it was good, clean fun, but some people REALLY got into it. Still, I'd recommend it.
author: Casey S.

description:
One of the best pillow fights of the year!!! 

I went into this not knowing what to expect. I called up some of my friends and told them there was a massive pillow fight in Sf after hearing about it on the internet, so we decided to go . I bought all my pillows , and when we got there, all we found was a mass amount of people throwing pillows at each other.

But the best part about it was, everyone was hitting each other with pillows. And no one was being serious about it, it was all for fun ! There were kids there and families, men and women. Police were there too, don't get me wrong, but they were merely there to make sure it doesn't get completely out of control. 

And pillows were scattered all over the place , so if you do bring your pillow, be prepared to lose your pillow, be also you will find another random pillow and can pick it up. 

Also a lot of people wer dressed up. Some in costume. There was a Santa, and a cowboy and a powerranger. Overall, everyone was having fun and just looking to have a great time , but remember to dress warm . The fight goes on till about 2 am or even later
author: Nick M.

description:
I was there this year for the pillow fight on Valentine's Day and honestly probably the worst decision I've done in my life. Did I enjoy? Unfortunately, NO! The pillow fight should've been just for fun for everyone. I thought it was kids friendly. Soon we arrived we encountered a bunch of aggressive fighter. I was swinging my pillow around and I hit a dude. A girl from his same group chase me down and smashed her pillow in my face. I asked her if this is necessary and she's like hell yeah you deserve it. WHAT THE HECK? It's supposed to be a frigging friendly pillow fight!!!! Anyways walking back to look for my friend some dude smacked me so hard that my contact fell out of my eye. I busted into tears and told myself I'll never come back. Seriously, if you're gonna play it aggressively, have your own fight at home. 
The night ended with some cat fight seeing a girl bleeding on the floor.
author: Yulin K.

description:
Such an amazing concept, a city sized pillow fight on Valentines Day.

I've never seen so many feathers in one place before.

It is well organized. The have security keeping an eye on things.

Totally random events like this, are one of the reasons I love San Francisco.
author: David T.

description:
From a bystander's perspective, this is novel and fun to watch. The beginning cheer to kick everything off brings a nostalgic and exciting energy to the event. But, once the novelty wears off, you're basically softly fighting strangers. Newcomers keep coming too because it's not always clear exactly when the thing starts and so it's not a critical mass where there's utter chaos (which is what I wanted). 

To make this a 5-star, I think I'd have to go with a big group, would want to let out some aggression, and would have to dress up in funny costumes with friends in order to make for fun photos. The actual experience is actually fun, but only for a hot minute.

If you're passing by, definitely join in. If you think this is going to be an epic event, please lower your expectations.
author: Christi D.

description:
The only flight club I would ever join.

Strangers join on Valentine's day to have a huge public pillow fight.  
People are ready to rumble so be prepared to throw down.  If you're more of a lover than a fighter, check who's around you because some people are rougher than others.  Bring a garbage bag, synthetic pillow (much easier to clean up) and a mask because feathers will fly.  It's like a therapy session with you and a thousand strangers.    

Pillow fight starts promptly at 5:45 pm when the Embarcadero clock dings.

There are rules to Pillow Fight Club

1) Tell everyone you know about Pillow Fight!

2) Tell EVERYONE YOU KNOW about Pillow Fight!!!

3) Nothing in your pillow but pillow.

4) Don't hit anyone without a pillow.

5) Don't hit anyone operating a camera.
author: Kristi G.

description:
So much chaos & fun!  

For the most part ppl played by the rules.  I got hit a little too hard a few times which was followed by an apology. Some ppl got too ruff but it was easy to spot who to stay away from right away.

Even with the policy there watching it was a smokers paradise... Smell of weed, & cigarette almost everywhere you turn.  The cops did what they could w/out being aggressive ("pls go smoke in the street").

This was a fun experience, probably won't do it again next year.  But defiantly something to try at least once!
author: Rhea C.

description:
Pillow Fight Veteran here going strong for 3 years. Every year you go, you learn some new tricks, practice old ones, but the fun factor is always there.
First, some warnings:

PILLOWS HURT. you don't think they do until you have a 300+ lb overweight man who towers 6 inches above you and smacks you head first with a pillow with the force of a car and your little 100 lb frame goes flying 5 feet in the other direction.

DON'T BRING DOWN FEATHER PILLOWS. there's nothing good about them. they're not as smackable, they rip and as you inhale the feather particles in you feel like you're 80 years old and can't breathe without the help of an oxygen tank. Also, it costs the city THOUSANDS of dollars to clean. cotton pillows only please

TEMPURPEDIC PILLOWS GRANTS YOU A TICKET TO HELL. ok not literally but they're not pillows. THEY'RE BRICKS. just hit yourself in the face with one and you'll know why.

DON'T BRING YOUR NASTY ASS DROOL/PISS STAINED PILLOW. first of all, some people sleep on GROSS pillows. two, I don't want that pillow near me kthxbai

DON'T HIT PEOPLE WHO DON'T HAVE A PILLOW. that's just mean dude.

NOTHING IN YOUR PILLOW BUT A PILLOW. one year I saw a guy tape a pillow to a POLE. A MOTHERFUCKING POLE. what are you trying to do?? kill people????

THE FIGHT STARTS AT 6PM SHARP! so get there early.

ALWAYS HIT THE OBVIOUS VALENTINES DAY COUPLE. because destroying cuteness is fun with pillows.


with all that out of the way, it is a super super super fun event! There are charity organizations around so bring cans to donate or pillows to donate. the city got smart and shut off the fountain near by so kids don't fall in or feathers clogging up the filter system. small kids will get lost in the crowd or suffer possible concussions so i don't recommend taking them here. in the end, it's a pillow fight! have fun, use common sense (see tips above) and stay safe!
author: Lanie L.

description:
Is it on for 2015? Nada anywhere online!!!!

Participated last year and had a blast with my friends!  Costumes, pillows swinging everywhere, & tiny feathers filling the air! Not for the faint of heart and definitely for the full of heart and laughter. SFPD was there to keep things under control. Loved the slow-mo fight with the dreadlocked guy!!!
author: Tom S.

description:
OMG! I heard about this event last year so I marked my calendar to attend this year. SOOOOOOO MUCH FUN!!!! 

It starts at 6:00 p.m. in the Justin Herman Plaza (great that it's right next to a BART station) and lasts until 9:00 p.m. ,though the crowd noticably dwindles as it gets close to 8:00 p.m. There are tons of looky-loos, standing on the perimeter, taking pictures. I highly recommend you wade into the thick of things and start swinging! :) I didn't wear any protective gear and managed to avoid serious injury. There are some douchebag guys who seem to be taking the whole thing way too serious and bring pillowcases that feel like they have sandbags in them. Avoid them at all costs-they are out for blood. I got hit hard a couple of times and  just got quickly away from them. Otherwise for the most part, it's good, clean fun (well, except for the feathers) and I even met a really cute guy who told me I was beautiful... right before I smashed him over the head with my pillow :)

It was a GREAT workout too!! Kind of like cardio kick-boxing. Next time I'll put my long hair in a ponytail, as I was a sweaty mess by the end. I lasted a good 45 minutes, going to the sidelines occasionally to regroup and catch my breath. 

The funniest part of the fight was this guy carrying a unicorn head. Whenever he came by, we all screamed "GET THE UNICORN!!!" and gang-pillowed him! I was screaming and laughing the whole time. 

The SF Pillow Fight will definitely be a VD tradition, as long as I am in the Bay Area!!
author: Wendy N.

description:
You know, the first couple of times this was funny.  Now that it is an annual thing that costs a lot of money - it's just a bunch of entitled hipsters out making a mess.  It's a sodding shame that people can't come up with more fun things to do - and even more shameful that some people make the excuse that "used" pillows are donated to charity (seriously - would you want that pillow?).

Do something more fun and rewarding with your time.  This event is as much a sham as anything else that has gone on too long - like "Santarchy" and all the rest of the formerly spontaneous & once quirky events.
author: Jenn C.

description:
I loved living in San Francisco. 

I loved the people, the international eateries, the pubs, the independent bookstores, the cable cars, the hills, the fog, the wind. 

But of all the wonderful memories of my year living in San Francisco, the night of pillow fight under the ferry building tower was without a doubt the most memorable. Hands down the most fun-packed half hour I have ever spent. The kind of fun you didn't think possible to have again as an adult. 

My heart stays in San Francisco.
author: Lori H.

description:
I survived the SF Pillow Fight!  Cough* a feather in my throat.  I only lasted but 8 minutes then I got tired.  The energy was great before it started, everyone lifted their pillows cheering like they do before war in the movies.  Then after the Ferry Building clock struck 6pm, game on.  I had fun, but some of those big dudes that just don't know when to stop, scared me.  I'm 5'3".  They jump into the air and then come down on you...smack, right on the head.

Notes:  Do not wear your glasses, put your valuables away.  Wear a mask on your face, seriously. Have a game plan if you split up from your group a landmark you can meet at.  Last have fun and watch out for those gangster bullies who want to F*#k You up.  Pillow Fight!!!
author: Michelle M.

description:
First rule about Pillow Fight Club: 

Tell everyone about Pillow Fight Club.

I managed to run into not one, but four friends, including one who we thought lived in another state because so many people came to this.

I officially love Pillow Fight Club. And will be back next year to get my head pummeled some more.
author: Meg T.

description:
Awesome & fun annual pillow fighting event at Justin Herman Plaza!
Hours: 6-9:30pm on Valentine's Day. If your arms don't get tired after 3 hours, then u can keep going as long as u want.

Here's a link to one of my favorite TV commercials: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jSbb9U6GPXE There are plenty of videos online about the real event, but I still prefer the TV ad.

SF (14th) and San Jose (13th) are the only cities who hold this free event on February (for Valentine's Day), most of the pillow fighting cities (+100: NY, LA, Chicago, Paris, Rome, London, Toronto, Montreal, Vancouver, Buenos Aires, Budapest, Prague, Dublin, Shanghai, Sydney, etc.) around the world celebrate around April, usually on a weekend.

- I hate breathing pillow feathers.
- Most people are decent, but some will try to hit u in the face.
- Camera wielding people should remain in the outskirts.
- Set of 3 standard bed pillows for $9.99 @Target, best deal in town!

To the guy using his cap to hit people instead of a pillow, you're an idiot!!

The rain convinced me to only be a spectator this time briefly before heading to dinner. Seems like the rain also affected attendance because I think there were less people this year compared to 2010.

The city complaints every year that it takes $17,500 (quoted from the newspaper) to clean up the streets after this event. That figure varies depending on who u ask, some say it's much higher after adding disposal costs. I always thought that city employees liked an excuse to get overtime. 

On the other hand, u could join a new group of volunteer do-gooders to clean up the area after the event (until 10:30pm). They also collect the pillows to donate to charity. http://pillowsforpuppies.tumblr.com/
author: Luis C.

description:
This is an experience that everyone should have. I mean come on, a citywide pillow fight? HOW could you pass up on that?

BUT, expect to get a couple bruises and scratches. You'd think that pillows are soft&cuddly&harmless, but NO. IT HURTS. When you endure 20+ blows to the head in the span of a minute, your head's gonna start ringing. You're gonna get elbowed, smacked, and straight up beaten up by a couple aggressive pillow-fighters. Some people mean serious business. Don't let this scare you though, because it's so much fun!

Some tips for the years to come:
1. Don't leave your mouth open for too long. It's tempting to yell battlecries all the time but you will probably start choking on feathers. My boyfriend, my friend, and I were all coughing pretty hard at the end of the night.

2. Be careful when you take out your phone to take a picture. You're probably not gonna get a good picture (I probably took 30+ iPhone pictures and none of them turned out nice), but at some point of the night, you should take a photo. HOLD ONTO THAT PHONE THOUGH. Someone smacked me with a pillow mid-photo and my phone went flying across the ground. No bueno. Grip onto your phone!!

3. Bring a pillow you don't really care for. 

4. Have fun!! Bring your date, your friends, or just yourself. I got separated from my group a couple times but it was still really fun, so bring your single self :)
author: Lisa N.

description:
THIS WAS BY FAR ONE OF THE BEST VALENTINES DAY that I had to spend alone because me and the boo were on other sides of the state, awesome as he is he said go enjoy yourself and do something.

So I was on bart from Dublin to SF. We arrived at 3 something to Embarcadero after roaming the streets of SF to kill some time. But once you get into the city you start to see others with pillows. Those that know what is going on don't see it as anything different. But once we arrived to Embarcadero there weren't many people, people just hanging out waiting for the clock to go off at 6pm. As the time came close more and more people began to show up.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GoCW_R-zsiE

I'll be back and hopefully my boo will be with me to hit a bunch of people with pillows!!
author: Steph S.

description:
MY PILLOW + YOUR FACE = GREAT TIMES
(5 stars + meteor shower)

What a way to get your aggression out on Valentine's weekend. More than a thousand San Franciscans bashing pillows into each others faces until it can't take it anymore. My favorite random event in SF and when I mean random, it is VERY random. Expect a crowd of all ages, sex, size, sexuality, etc. OH, and expect a few creepies in the crowd. Be prepared, there are some disturbing looking pillows with all kinds of nasty stains on them that will be hitting you, so i suggest to do your best to avoid people who'd be grimmy like that.

 They have it at the perfect location, Justin Herman Plaza. Right where you can see the clock from the Ferry Building strike 6PM. And the face bashing goes on for hours, feathers flying everywhere, and everyone screaming laughing and have a good time. I may be a chick with small stature but I sure have knocked out some people (captured on video for proof). 

1. drink lots of energy drinks (and alcohol)
2. come early
3. take public transportation
4. keep it clean
5. your pillow = their face

For all you newbs, don't stand there and hit people around you. MOVE THROUGH THE CROWD (it's alot more fun that way). 

Until the next review....
author: Jane A.

description:
There are few things better than a bunch of people standing around, calmly talking, anxiously waiting for the Embarcadero bell tower to ring so the mayhem can begin. You'll make new friends and in a matter of minutes you'll pummel each other til feathers fill the air.

Pro tips: 
1. Don't wear glasses or have your cell phone out. Both will go flying.
2. Prepare to get feathers everywhere. Your clothes, your eyes, your lungs...
3. Bring a pillow that has a natural filling, no polyester foam or artificial beads, the beads hurt and if it breaks they may end up in the bay.
4. Watch out for the guys taking it a little too seriously. You'll know them when you see them, their rampage pays no respect to anyone or anything.
5. Respect the kids on the outside, I mean literal kids there with their parents, it can be fun to trade a few with the five year old on his dad's back, but if some idiot hits dad, the kid goes down (I've seen it happen, see #4).
6. Prepare for rain or shine. 
7. Make friends, it always helps to have allies in a pillow fight!

PS to the single men: acts of chivalry are usually respected on Valentine's Day.
author: Tyler W.

description:
Imagine with me, if you will, a world whose air is filled with feathers and cotton stuffing. A place where violent pummeling is not only commonplace, but encouraged. Puddles are booby traps for brand new pillow cases to fall and get ruined in. 

This is the Valentine's Day Pillow Fight. 

It's fun, it's legal, and it's only once year. So don't miss it!

The only downsides to this event are the crooks that take advantage of the uninhibited bags and pockets. Also, some people don't know when to stop. 
But it IS fun.
author: Melanie P.

description:
I attended my first pillow fight this year, it really is the best thing to do on Valentines Day! Imagine a couple of hundred people wailing on each other with pillows for three hours; although I don't know how anyone could stand to fight for longer than an hour.

I recommend wearing a bandanna over your mouth, as it can get rather difficult to breath with all the flying feathers! 

There are times during the fight when groups of people will rush in like a raid, from outside the fight this kind of looks like brave heart reenacted with pillows. If your female I would suggest getting out of the way when this happens to avoid being pushed over, or groped. Any type of fight is bound to be a testosterone driven event. As long as you don't let a few carried away people ruin your perception of the event and you will have a great time.
author: Natasha W.

description:
This gives me a high similar to that of a roller coaster ride! I laughed to the point of cramps! We gather in the masses with our pillows or other stuffed pillow-like contraptions, watch the clock of the Ferry Building, and at the strike of 6 PM, we freak the huck out!!! My four-foot-eleven-inch ass gets done! I don't know who I'm hitting or who's hitting me. I can tell they're hitting hard, but it doesn't hurt a bit cuz my adrenaline is on "freak out" mode. I'm not sure how the pillow fight lasts as long as it does. After ten to fifteen minutes, my ass is drained! It's a test of endurance! Originally started as an Anti-Valentine's Day event, you'll notice an increasing amount of happy couples joining in on the fun. This is a BLAST!!!

Please bring pillows filled with all-natural materials. We are near the water and the wind carries the materials out to the Bay.
author: Helen L.

description:
By far the BEST thing to do on Valentine's Day. Even if you're a couple. Which I wasn't. So it made it even BETTER! 

I was kind of a wuss though... I only waded in for a little bit and then ran out.  And a few other notes: 

-Next year, bring a helmet. 

-To those that brought tempurpedic pillows, may ugly monkeys gnaw on your face! They're freaking BRICKS! 

-Bring FRESH pillows. We don't want your nasty drool infused, dandruff laden, sweat soaked yuckies anywhere near us!
author: Evie D.

description: Came to my first pillow fight and it was interesting to see perfect strangers beating each other with pillows. I see a lot of people with brand new pillows so it does help the local Ross and Marshalls in their pillow sales. Then helps all the food dealers around, like Osha Thai and 7-11 for those who were just interested in a drink. I know Hyatt wasn't too happy having all these people rush in to use their restrooms.
author: M C.

description:
I finally attended this year and it was a blast. Next year I will leave my camera at home, but this time I around I took it with me. Here are some pics. 

http://photosophic.com/blog/?p=1513
author: Alejandro M.

description:
Ah.  The beauty of SF.  The joy.  Romance.

F*** Valentine's Day.  

It is one of the largest scams in history driven by capitalist intentions.  This is not reminiscent of an era where love letters were carefully written and delivered, despite the rain/sleet/snow.  Or when a lock of hair was sent to an admirer.  Or a Nocturne is composed and dedicated to the love of their life.  Ah.  Now that is romantic.

The scam is that the usual bouquet of roses triple in cost.  The aisles of every retail establishment is bursting at the seams with crimson objects of artificial affection.  Single women feel like crap if they don't get anything or have someone listed as their +1.  Hopeless romantics that make me rolI my eyeballs all the way back Beetlejuice style.  I'm not bitter.  I've had my fair share of V-day.  I even had three ridiculously large bouquets delivered to my place of employment once by the same guy but they all died within a week.  Couple $$$ out the door.  And who can really consume 2 pounds of chocolate?  That is the perfect amount of fat I need extracted from my butt.

No.  I'm just getting too old.  And time is too precious to waste.  Having expectations is the worst curse anyone can do to themselves.  Why wait until this day to profess a love for someone when you can do it everyday! 

A big hug.  

A bright smile.  

Warm thoughts.  

Words of affection.

This is where the SF Pillow Fight Club steps in with a reality check and curbs your enthusiasm with a big bag of down in your face.  Hanging out with a positive crowd and bonking someone on the head with a good goose down pillow (the feathers kind of poke) is the best kind of love give/take.  It is fluffy.  Warm.  And if you need to hug someone, viola!  Hug the pillow.  And not to mention, lots of fun.  Taking a pillow to the head, stepping away when the feathers get blown out of proportion and one is sporting a new down afro.  Picture perfect.  

Making new friends amidst the company of old.  Making plans with friends to get some hot coffee or hot chocolate. Evading guys trying to ask for your number (see, there are possibilities).  Departing with hugs and new friendships.  Getting out of my car and leaving bits of down here and there.  

Now that's what I call a truly special day.

Priceless.
author: Miika M.

description:
SO MUCH FUNNN!

For all those other lonely hearts, this is a great night out for friends on the dreaded Valentine's Day. Haha, just kidding! Kind of. You can bring a date too. :) Prepare to smack people and get smacked around, wage mini-battles against strangers, breathe in a ton of feathers, and have an amazing night. :D 

A few things to keep in mind:
- Come with friends! Safety and more fun in numbers. It's easy to get lost in the crowd or get mobbed if you're not careful, so it helps to have buddies to back you up.
- Bring a synthetic pillow and face mask/scarf/something to cover your mouth. Seriously, breathing in those feathers is so not the business. It's entertaining at first, but you won't feel the same once you start coughing. No bueno. :(
- Bring a camera! The ferry building and the plaza are gorgeous at night with the giant, action-packed flurry of people and beautiful lights. You will get some amazing pictures, but definitely be careful as attacks can come out  of nowhere and damaging/losing your phone or pricey camera is never fun.
- Some people can be a little too aggressive. There is plenty of security on the sidelines keeping an eye out, but sometimes things get lost in the chaos, and people get hurt. :( So, again, bring friends to be safe and watch out who you decide to pick a fight with. A few bumps and bruises are alright here and there, but my friend got knocked out cold when he got lost by himself. That part of the night I don't want to repeat ever again. :( BE CAREFUL!
- Some people bring their kids, and I mean YOUNG kids. Ummm. Yeah, no, I'd be terrified for my tiny child. Just make sure you don't run one over by accident. 

So anyway, just be safe and (mostly) considerate, and you're good to go. :) I promise you it's worth trying at least once.
author: Grace T.

description:
There aren't many occasions in life where you can walk into a mob of strangers and beat them silly with a pillow, and this is one of them.

It happens every year on Valentines day...bring a pillow you don't value and leave your glasses at home!

Come on down and whack the crap out of everyone! Short people beware! Hehehe......It's on!
author: Grace Y.

description:
Here's a blow by blow ;-) of the SF Pillow Fight:

WHACK WHACK!   SMACK OUCH!   HAHAHA!   FEATHERS POOF!   HEY!   BAM SMACK DOH!   MORE FEATHERS!   SMASH      GGRRRRR!   hello cutie   POW   WTH?  LAUGHTER   CRUNCH!   ring ring HELLO?   BAM WHACK!   ACK!   TIME OUT! TIME OUT!   SMOOSH   COUGH COUGH  I SWALLOWED A FEATHER!   ACK!   SMASH!   HAHAHA!

Free fun! Don't be a spectator, jump in. This sport is tiring though. I took a couple of breathers on the sideline and was able to last 30 minutes. We're talking pillow fighting, mmmkay? After a while, my arms got tired and I just hit the shorties from then on. I was surprised when I saw some little kids there. Little ones should be cautious of going in the center because it's thick with bodies and flying elbows. It was a trip unexpectedly running into friends and yelpers in the middle of the mayhem and then WHACK!  Best PILLOW-GING were outside the center where you can stare down your opponent; take bigger swings; and run around. 

Suggestions:
-  Get there early
-  No eyeglasses
-  Bring friends (even kids 10 yrs+)
-  Clean/new pillowcase
-  CamelBak with choice of refreshment
author: Teddy B.

description:
"HEY! Quit it! Watch the hair! Now why don't you pick on someone your own size..."

"Feathers, everywhere! Shit, they're in my eyes now! AAAHHH they sting... hey where you'd go... OUCH!"

"Hey, watch it! This is a 300-dollar camera I'm holding! It... ACK! WTF! You broke it, asshole!! You'll pay for that...."

"Can't *coughcough*... breathe *coughcough*... choking on *COUGH*... feathers..."

"My head... my head..."

San Francisco Pillow Fight: NOT FOR COMPLAINERS!

Note to self for next year: bring helmet and goggles.
author: Kate V.

description:
Free, fun and releases tension!

I had a blast. 

Warning to people with cameras: if you go in the middle of the mosh put you WILL get hit. People don't do it on purpose but it's chaos and people will nail you. I purposely took my 50mm lens since I knew it was less likely to get broken in the melee. 

I was choking on feathers about 3 minutes into it. Glad I had some water in my backpack. Next year I'm definitely taking something to cover my mouth,

Pictures: http://www.flickr.com/photos/calmenda/sets/72157603912127806/
author: Carlos A.

description:
This is the closest it'll ever get to snowing in SF... and with February raining in temperatures of 30 degrees plus windchill, you don't even need snow! Feathers are fluffy, beautiful and dry. And they also provide for excellent snow angels. 

February 14, 2009. I can still taste the Joseph Schmidt Irish coffee truffle (oh, the days!)  melting on my lips as a half-torn pillow whacks me in the face and nearly rips the ski parka off my shivering body. 

It was absolutely lovely. :)

Bottom Line: A free way to spend an expensive day.
author: Tianyi S.

description:
This Feb 14th was the first SF Valentine's Pillow Fight I've attended and it was a blast. The commotion, crowds, spirit, fun, and sheer jubilation was great way to spend part of Vday evening in the city. The crowd was massive. I heard that previous years had 2,000 to 4,000 participants. There were tons of people spectating on the sidelines, loads of photographers cruising about the herds of people with their fancy cameras and gear, and loads just in it to hit-and-get-hit by swinging pillows. Although the official start time was 6pm, the action went well beyond 30+ minutes into a beautiful, clear SF night with NO FOG or wind chill Sunday night. It was THE PERFECT setting for all the crazy madness!

I definitely recommend for all to come see or take part in this festive annual event down in the Embarcadero's Justin Herman Plaza. It's great with friends or just by yourself. Something different from the everyday, monotonous routines. Come enjoy and experience it! I know I'll be back for more next year and beyond. Cheers!!!
author: L C.

description:
Hands down, this is one of the best experiences I've ever had.

I came here 5 years ago, and my memory of the day is still just as crystal clear. My boyfriend at the time drove me out to San Francisco on Valentine's day, giving no indication of our plans what-so-ever. Held a bag with two pillows, but I was still clueless. We went to Embarcadero Square around 5:45pm and sat around waiting. Still, I didn't know what was going on. Sure, I noticed other people strangely hanging around the square, holding over-sized bags, and anxiously watching the clock tower, but the dots didn't really connect for me until the clock struck 6 o'clock and people ran into the center with their pillows held high.

Definitely not what I was expecting!

We split up and entered the crowd separately. I got my good share of hits and some elbowing, but I didn't care. I was having a blast attacking random strangers, enjoying the silly costumes of others, and soaking in the excitement and energy of the crowd. My favorite part of the night was when pillow-fight participants using down-pillows wore out their weapons. When the pillows broke, a great release of feathers would fly into the air, having some semblance of snow. It's really beautiful, but also deadly to the lungs! I even proceeded to making a feather angel on the ground.

I hope I can make it out to the Great San Francisco Pillow Fight again. I had the greatest time. But this time, I will surely be prepared with a down pillow and some hefty armor for protection!
author: Emily T.

description:
Hmm,

I feel like a total idiot for not giving this 5-stars.  The idea of this event is 5+ stars, no doubt.

However, the weather and crowds did seem to be a factor.  I thought this was a cool event.  The Bart station stairs were a total hassle (just assume that the escalators are closed would be a good idea).

I went there to primarily shoot pictures, which I should have arrived earlier.  I got their at 5:55, and was basically on the outside looking in.  You could dive right into the mosh pit d'oreiller, but with my camera I decided to just stay on the edges.

I was pleasantly surprised at the number of couples that were at this... As odd as it may sound, one could make this a decently romantic way to start your Valentine's Day evening.  I know that was the intent, but ...

So, get their early (earlier if you a photographer looking to capture the chaos), don't freak out because you have to walk the stairs at the Bart station, and don't imitate Sean Penn from Bad Boys in your pillow selection.
author: Will A.

description:
A fun Valentine's Day activity (PG-13 event) for all except kids... keep them at home. There's a chance they'll get hurt or trampled. 

Bring your own pillow or else you'll get stuck with purchasing one for $20+ from people on the street! And like someone else suggested, bring a bandana because you'll easily choke on feathers unless you like that kind of thing. 

It's nice how this event brings all kinds of different people together. The crowd is huge and diverse. I also love how people are either whacking you out of laughter or anger.
author: Bets Y.

description:
Definitely a San Francisco institution... and less "flash mob" per se... there's no flash about it since it lasts quite a long time. Could be summarized as an amazingly silly and memorable time. I've done this event for 3 years as the kick off for my Valentine's evening plans. A good way to get the angst out. 

Photographers will always catch you "at your best" when you're getting smacked about by dozens of pillows. The only way to combat is with a strategic preemptive pillow smackdown on your adversaries in the crowd. I go "in theme" attire which makes people either want to just gawk and appreciate, saving me from pillow brutality and earning me a bit more respect. 

In any case, wearing some gear over your eyes and nose/mouth (avoid inhaling)... and wear clothes which you might want to not see for a while or have professionally cleaned after is a must... the feathers are dense and stick to everything. Lookup video to know what to expect in the throes of the largest pillowfight one will probably ever go to.
author: Diana F.

description:
I've never had this much fun dispensing unprovoked beatdowns on total strangers.  I think the poor, unknowing passerbys were a bit confused when the Ferry Building tower struck 6PM and Justin Herman  Plaza looked like something out of Braveheart, sans the battle axes, sub soft, fluffy sacks.  The initial yell and charge by the 100+ combatants was hilarious, and stopped a few business suits cold in their tracks.  Turns out pillows can, in fact, invoke terror.

In the end, regardless of how mighty I may have felt, I must embarrassingly concede that it was the geese who had the last laugh.  Ever tried to breathe feathers?  Not one or two feathers.  Try the 2348329048 Cort Z. mentioned.  To experience this, follow as instructed:

1) Find a big, fluffy down pillow.
2) Find a box cutter.
3) Find a large funnel.
4) Find a friend.
5) Find an industrial strength leaf blower.
6) Hold funnel between teeth, pillow at arms length in one hand, shiny new box cutter in another.  Position yourself in front of friend with the leaf blower.
7) Have friend turn leaf blower on maximum setting and aim the resulting Category 5 directly at your face.  Raise pillow to eye level.  Slash pillow with box cutter.  Suck the funnel like a nicotine addicted asthmatic sucks an inhaler.

Like I said, the geese had the last laugh.
author: Quinn Z.

description:
I went to my first pillow fight yesterday and had a blast.

It was an unique, interesting experience and at times, I felt that I was in a mosh pit. Feathers everywhere! 

If you plan to do this, make sure to remove hats, scarfs, or anything small that you don't want to lose. Also very accessible to Bart. It was amusing to watch people's reactions when they saw other fellow riders holding pillows and have no clue on what was going on.
author: Rhoda G.

description:
It was Valentine's day? Really? I seriously forgot. But just for the fact it was Valentine's day I am docking a star. LOL. Anyways, it was brilliant! I'm quite sure this was the biggest one yet. The only thing is, people hit me with pillows and I had a bunch of cameras on me. I was even standing in the safety zone, sup with that? Next year, I'm bringing pillows. In fact, I'm planning to double fist two small throw pillows so I can move faster with them. It's kung fu pillow time, beezy. 

Revenge of the photographer, that's the new tag line next year. That's right, don't even sleep tonight. I know you can't after reading this. I hope you know where your kids are, yeah, look at your watch. Did you take ballet as a child? I bet you did. Have I struck a nerve yet? Yeah? Bring it on. 

You want an exhibition pillow match? How about we raise the stakes and fight Michael Jackson's "Beat it" style and tie our hands together, huh? Did you train in the mountains like I did? Do you have every single Rocky soundtrack in your iPod like I do? Do you drink RAW milk straight from the cow's teet? I don't think so. And that's why I'm going to beat you. You train with pixie sticks and beef jerky while I train with wedding cake and a fire extinguisher. You better believe it. You won't be sleeping tonight....

I recommend sleeping pills.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ysURTuWec2s

- Ry
author: Ryan R.

description:
Do you want to laugh and giggle for 20 minutes straight while whacking strangers and trying not to get a concussion? Then you must check out this event.

I'm a huge fan of the SF pillow fight! I went this past Valentine's Day and had an absolute blast hitting random strangers with my fluffy white pillow and getting smacked on the head every 2 seconds. Luckily, the people in my vicinity didn't feel a need to dole out concussions, so I didn't have to worry about head injuries (even though I was warned by a friend that some people do get quite aggressive and that things can get ugly).

The feathers that float above the crowd make for an awesome snowglobe ambiance. You just sorta get that feeling that you just love SF and all the great people around you who are hitting you across the face with their old pillows.

I'm knocking off a star because everyone was choking on feathers - I had white dust in my eyes, in my mouth, in my throat. Next year, I am definitely bringing one of those swine flu masks and swim goggles...I will look especially attractive next year, yesss.

Highly recommended. Go!
author: Amy D.

description:
I come and its a blast every year.

It's always fun seeing people with pillows as well on their way to the ferry building as we look at each other and hold our pillows up.

FYI, bring a bandana to put over your mouth, feathers evidently end up getting into your mouth very easily.

Down fall: The clean up for feathers after the pillow fight end up costing the city over $10,000 (according to the news)

Its also gets kind of rough so think twice about brining kids.
author: Kameron K.

description: Get's bigger every year and I cannot wait! I love it! Cover your mouth since there will be feathers flying. Beware of kids on dad's shoulders who will bonk you on the head and little teens who hit way too hard. Other wise ENJOY! If they have a pillow they are fair game.
author: Natasha M.

description:
*thwap thwap thwap*

no, that's not the sound of some naked person's body parts flapping away in the unforgiving san francisco wind. [that's *fwap fwap*]

it's the sound my pillow makes as it makes contact with your head.

*thwap thwap thwaaaap*
author: Tinna H.

description:
Girl in Purple....I hope you thought about what you did when you came at me with that dirty pillow of yours.  That's right, I took you out and made you cry and run away.  No body, I mean NOBODY can get me in a pillow fight! 

Haha, my 2nd year to this and it still cracks me up when you go and theres a bjillion people just throwing down with pillows.  The guy on the bike and speakers blasting music and leading the train was awesome.  I hit so many people in that train.  But unfortunately, with all the feathers around, I was starting to lose my lungs, so I had to tap out.

See you all again next year!  Same time, same day!  

p.s. please people...wear your deoderant...do us all a favor
author: Vincent K.

description:
first time going to one yesterday!!!!

Awesome experience! I would have loved to take my camera and did some shooting but I wouldn't have been able to smack some with my pillow giving to me by my girlfriend with hearts and team GeDi on it.

Hate those people who hit and run like babies. Come and fight me like a man/woman/both, hey it's SF.

Till next year and I hope I get to smack you right in the face with all of the love in the world!

Disclaimer: Bring pillow of course, helmet, face cover, armour and your willingness to swing and abuse at the most legal sense.
author: Gerard L.

description:
This year, Rachael W and I co-planned the most amazing Valentines that I (and my 49 single friends) have had to date... "Cupid's Folly: Napa Party Bus '09" was a singles party bus to celebrate Valentine's with our fellow attractive single friends (and their friends) who were also not getting chocolates or flowers on February 14th.

8 hour wine tour through Napa- limo bus, 3 wineries (well, technically we only actually made it to 2), lots of booze, lots of dancing, lots of mingling, lots of fun

And where did our Bauer's limo bus drop us off as our final destination? Well the infamous SF Pillowfight of course.

There's nothing quite like celebrating the end of an amazing 8 hours of wine tasting with some good old fashioned pillowfighting. Feathers EVERYWHERE- at one point I was told it would be a good idea to get on the ground and make "snow angels" with all the feathers on the ground. For whatever reason (I'm guessing the wine is to blame) I obliged.

Still picking feathers out of my purse, but at least it's finally out of my hair! Already counting down to next year. Our first annual singles Valentines was a blast, but hopefully one day, eventually, I'll be in a relationship and won't be the one planning the, let's say, 6th annual haha
author: Brianna H.

description:
I LOVE IT! 
Last night was awesome! I took lots of photos and people had fun and it was an all around good time! I got wacked only a few time since I was picture taking but I know the rules and since I was near the center, I expected it. The late addition DJ was pretty cool!  And the tunnel of pillows was funny. If you missed it, you missed a great pillow party! Some people even came in their pj's! If it's still on next year, you should go!

Oh! it's good for little kids but only with parents around and as long as they are on the outskirts of the mob. Much safer that way.
author: Fran S.

description: This is a horrible event and should be stopped! The feathers that are in the pillows come from birds who suffered in unimaginable ways and for what? so a bunch of people can destroy some pillows?! what a horrible waste. Please buy pillows made without feathers and don't participate in this extremely wasteful and cruel event.
author: Critic M.

description:
Single, in a relationship, or married... this event is an exciting place to be during Vday!  My husband did me right by bringing me here before a good hearty beer at Gordon Biersch!

FYI free/easy street parking (since even is close to 6pm), cool crowd, and great SF location!
author: Natalie O.

description:
I just had the BEST Valentine's Day ever and it didn't even involve my boyfriend!
Wait. That came out kind of wrong.
It gets worse...I was with 3 male companions working up a sweat with objects from the bedroom.
Feathers were flying, I was shrieking in delight and they were pretty happy too.
After 2 long hours, we were spent.
......

It's moments like these when I am profoundly glad my boyfriend doesn't have a Yelp account because I would seriously be grounded.
author: Jill D.

description:
Whether you're out to release some V-Day angst or just want to be a part of something that you won't be able to stop talking about for days, weeks, or even years, I highly....HIGHLY recommend that you check this out. 6 years running and the number of attendants to this event keeps on growing. My friends and I had the opportunity to experience it for the first time last night. You can choose to either participate or be a spectator, but why stay out of the fun? It only happens once a year! 

Just be aware that most people will take the words "pillow fight" to a whole new level. This isn't your average sleepover-type pillow fight. No contest! There will be some aggressive ones out there who are not afraid to throw down. I even called a kid out because I could have sworn he stuffed a few rocks into his pillow. Karma bit him in the behind later as he was ambushed by at least 10 other people who felt his wrath. If you simply cannot stand having your lovely face thrashed with pillows, then I suggest you be a bystander. Yes, it's gonna happen and you have no way of avoiding it whatsoever. So quit yer b*tchin' and deal with it, otherwise you're not going to enjoy yourself. It's also a smart idea to have something to cover your mouth with (e.g. bandana, surgical mask, etc.) My throat got pretty dry at one point from inhaling the down particles floating around. Dress up comfortably and preferably cover up from head to toe, unless you don't mind getting debris on your designer mini dress and marks on your expensive heels/limited edition sneaks. Would you really do that?! Come on. 

This was my best Valentine's Day experience to date. I don't know about the rest of you who went, but I'm feeling extremely sore and will probably be that way for the next few days. I'll have to remember to stretch out before heading into the mayhem next year.
author: Rhia R.

description:
Just woke up from 4 days of coma after being totally beat up by strangers with feathery weapons. 

Ok, i might be exaggerated but dang, people are pillow fighting like it's going out of style!

Still not as dangerous as the Running of the Bulls and not as messy as the Tomatina.

Basically a huge stress ball to squeeze on. And get squeezed in. 

Should it become a weekly event?  I vote possibly maybe.
author: Margie B.

description:
This was frankly, the most liberating & awesome experience of my days. 
A pillow fight. in San Francisco. With people of ALL ages. Epic.
And it was HILARIOUS to go to BART & see all of the people with the pillows - and be asked 478429749 times why I was carrying one around.
Then, came the fight. People were mostly friendly, no creepers in my vicinity. But damn, it hurt to get straight on the head with the angry force of a pillow.
I really don't get how anyone could have survived for over an hour in there. I was coughing up feathers for a week.
"I AM THOR WITH THIS PILLOW!"--- best comment addressed to me. 
Some folks even wore SARS masks & helmets.
Totally awesome!
author: Jessica G.

description:
Pillow fights rule.

Tell everyone about Pillow Fight.
Tell EVERYONE about Pillow Fight.
Wait for the ferry building clock to strike 6.
Don't hit people with a pillow unless they want it.
Don't hit anyone with a camera.
HAVE FUN!!!!!

Yup. Check out our Facebook group ;)
author: Eddie P.

description:
Best. Valentine's Day activity. EVER.

The fun started with our festive bus o' pillow fighters, and it lasted long after we stopped pummeling everyone in sight with fluffy pillows. My girlfriends and I went in with a team name and fightin' strategy, and I think it's safe to say we were victorious. Add a little pizza and fro-yo to the equation, and you've got yourself a perfect Valentine's Day.

(Yes, I may have feathers in my hair, lungs, and clothing for the next several days... but it's well worth it!)
author: Sam S.

description:
Me (to friends before the fight started): So how long you think we are going to be in this tihng.

Friend: Well my roommate said it kinda dies down and gets lame after an hour.

Me: There is no way you can have a pillow fight for one hour. But we can just meet at Noah's.

Me (seven minutes later at Noah's): That was fun, but I think I lost my virginity twice...time to get wasted.

Definitely a fun event to say I went to, but if I go back next year I will:

a) bring a larger group of peeps/be more popular so I see more friends
b) get black out drunk
author: Andrew K.

description:
Cost for a replacement pillow: $10

Cost for a glasses case because I forgot one and didn't want to get bent out of shape due to my glasses getting bent out of shape: $4.50

Grand total: $14.50



At these prices, who the fuck needs therapy? 

To those wearing dust masks - at first I thought you were wearing them for fun and silliness, but now I know it's because you're pillow-fighting veterans, and this newbie salutes you.
author: Sus... B.

description:
Hello pillow fighters and pillow lovers!

New rules for this year:

1. Donate your FIBER pillow to a Pillows for Puppies station when you're done!
2. Bring FIBER pillows to donate. Shelters only take fiber pillows due to allergies.
3. Trash bags and gloves for all! Let's leave the park sparkling clean!

This year you can donate your fiber-filled pillows to Pillows for Puppies, and we'll distribute them to local charities! Your weapon of soft destruction can go to a great cause. Find a donation station and drop off your pillow.

Please email us to volunteer. Meet other nice, community-oriented people. Yes, you are welcome to both fight and volunteer! 
PillowsforPuppies@gmail.com
http://pillowsforpuppies.tumblr.com
author: Jen S.

description:
This was the funnest Valentine's Day I've ever had (:
My friends & I took BART there, along w/30 other participants. We were all really excited & couldn't wait. Right when we got there, everyone already started. &I lost my friends within the first second of getting into the huge crowd. I eventually found them like, twenty minutes later. Before then I hit some guy in the face that had glasses, beat up a midget, & helped knock some guy off of the shoulders of some other guy. This was really fun, but after a long while, my arms started to hurt, I swallowed a few feathers, & I had a small headache from getting ganged up on by three guys with hardhats -___-; But overall, I loved it (: I'm most definitely going back this year.
author: Denise N.

description:
Just awesome. This is what I made my bf do with me for V-day. Forget the commercialization. Instead, go hit strangers with pillows or watch others do so. There were even some zombie pillow fighters and "UN Inspectors" who gave out tickets. Plus, looks like snowfall when the pillows rip open and feathers fly everywhere. (Debbie Downer moment: there are serious cleaning problems with the event. The feathers clog up drains and there are flooding issues at the buildings surrounding the area the next day.)

At a pub later that night, the hostess had feathers in her and she said this event reminded her of why she loves San Francisco. Me too.  I heart San Francisco.
author: Yan E.

description: Great fun! my 10 year old son had a great time - he was able to go right into the middle with the help of some of the guys in our group. Smaller kids stayed to the periphery. Lots of college aged kids. Mostly everyone seemed to play fair and looked out for one another while they beat each other with smiling faces. We will def go again! Fun way to spend Valentine's eve.
author: Jessica H.

description:
This really was one of the best things I did in San Francisco.

It's about fun!  All about fun!!!!!

You choke on feathers for a little bit once the fight gets heated, but its fine, you get used to it after they line your entire throat.

I had a blast here two years ago, and look forward to going to it again this year!!!

Not much else to be said!!!
author: Jess R.

description:
Scenario: Anti-celebration of VD in 2009 with a few friends.  I told everyone I could about Pillow Fight Club.  I haven't seen the pics yet but I'm anticipating great things since one just bought a really nice camera and lens.  I'm sure there were some other people there I knew but never found to show them my love, which equals a good tolchok to the head.

Product: Well, nothing's being sold, except maybe your soul for the chance to wallop some schmuck upside the head with a large bed pillow and know no repercussions will be forthcoming.  In other words, AWESOME value.

Service: Hmmm, people wearing helmets... You'd think that was cheating but it actually draws attention.  It's a great SERVICE to all the other pillow fighters because it's liking painting a giant red bulls eye on your head.  It also provides great energy and motivation as arm and shoulder muscles begin to fatigue.  Take the second wind I just described and multiple it by, say, 30 and that's what wearing a thong as a 5'4" scrawny caucasian does.  Disclaimer: I'm 6'5" so that was NOT me.  Being so tall was actually a disservice to myself... little people, why you gotta hate?!?  Oh, and the UN peacekeepers provided a great service by toting out victims on stretchers.  Last but not least, people were giving me crap about having a small pillow... at least it wasn't an airplane pillow.  Really?  You know who you are, bring the big guns next time.

Atmosphere: hot, stuffy, people pushing and shoving and yelling, feathers a-flying... general mayhem until about a half hour in when people start getting pooped and call for reinforcements.  This is the -1.  It was too crowded, or I'm too tall and my arms are too long, to really rev up a good swing every time.

Uniquity: They had pillow fights in the quad at UC Davis so this isn't all that unique.  But it's great times and a way to let out some stress on V Day, especially if the world hasn't seen fit to bless you with a date with that special someone afterward.
author: Robert R.

description: Fun as hell!! Crazy! Prepare for war!!!
author: Kyle J.

description:
I must admit I was a little worried this event would just be painful because I always recalled pillow fights being just a good way to create a nice headache and some one ultimately getting hurt...but this was fantastic and SO funny....I couldn't stop laughing and I loved just swinging my pillow around at random people ( I apologize for those close calls to people with cameras or what not but if you're going to stand right in the middle of a pillow fight with your camera...well the chaos just might get you and your camera...so really you brought it on yourself didn't you?) Let me tell you, watch out for those little kids with pillows, they come from below and they can swing with the best of them. I gave one no mercy as we swung at each other....totally funny! Rock on little man!!
I love this kind of event where people just let go and have simple fun. I can't imagine what it must have been like to have to clean up the mess of feathers but God bless those people who did.
author: Veronika A.

description:
A perfect way to celebrate an Anti-Valentines day with friends (and plenty of strangers).

Tips for next year:
- Find a real goose-feather pillow. They explode so much cooler.
- Work out delts. That way I can hit people for longer than 5 minutes.
- Get a SARS mask.  I was coughing up feathers for two days.
- It is okay to do drive-by pillow bashings outside of the designated area.
- It's just like grade-school.  Nothing says "You are cute" like a pillow flying toward their face.
author: Ronald M.

description:
Going to this reminded me that I am a pretty small person.  There's nothing like a 220 pound dude whacking you in the back of the head with a pillow as hard as he possibly can.

Besides that, IT IS SO FUN.  I gave it four stars instead of five because I started gagging on feathers about 10 minutes into it.  How disgusting is that?  What kind of bird did those feathers really come from?  How old is that pillow?

Here are a few tips in no particular order:

1. Remember to take off your glasses ahead of time.
2. Bring some water to rinse the feathers out of your mouth. (ew)
3. Make sure you bring a pillow case or something (we used t-shirts) so you can get a good grip on your pillow when swinging it around.
4. Don't wait until the absolute last minute to go to Ross to buy a cheap pillow.  Everyone else will have beaten you to the punch.
5. Be kind -- watch the elbows.

About halfway into it, I couldn't handle it anymore so I just stood on the tables near the hotel and mall.  I gave my pillow to a curious business traveler who wanted to have at it and he actually brought it back.  For weeks after, you could see feathers in the grass and in the planters around the trees.  Classic.
author: Tamara M.

description:
Maybe I'm getting old (im 20?) but this event hurt.  It'd be more fun if people didn't try to knock you out with their pillows.

I got sucker punched by a 4 ft tall girl and she chased after me to annihilate my stomach.  That was scary, she was one of those devil children!

Things to bring next time:
-Not my glasses (wear contacts or bring a hard case)
-some kind of face mask to protect against the plague floating in the air.
-Lint roller.
author: Peter v.

description: This fight single-handedly managed to reconciled me with Valentine's Day. The opportunity to watch and take part in epic single combats, massive brawls, and a lot of cool strangers around, in summary everything one could want. Due to lack of supplies, I had to bring a teddy bear instead of a pillow, and I definitely recommend it as an alternative experience.
author: Abel M.

description:
A great free event to do on Valentine's Day, whether or not you have a Valentine. This is a great alternative to doing anything else when you don't have a Valentine because you are not going to get remind every minute of your night of how you *don't* have a Valentine. Everything you've read in the other reviews is true: it's fun, there are lots of feathers and laughter, and you can get hit so hard that you may need a chiropractic adjustment. 

BTW: An upholstered sofa seat is *not* a pillow, you sick, sadistic puppies!

In addition to the other tips that you've read in the other reviews: do not wear a wool coat under any circumstances. I wore my red wool coat in honor of Valentine's Day and I used up my entire roll of lint remover tape and there are *still* feathers on my coat. And stand close to people with soft pillows. (See above note re: sofa cushions.)

If you are wondering how to take pix and participate in the fight, just do both, but not at the same time. I didn't last very long in the actual fight and was able to rest in the sidelines and take pix, except I didn't bring my camera.
author: Leah F.

description:
I had a blast! Check out my video of the madness: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=befu4gtwDbU

It was great!

N
author: Nick V.

description:
This event was a reminder of why I love San Francisco!

description:
Those of you who love taking pictures...this review is for you:

If you have a digital camera, it probably came with a wrist strap. I, like many of you, upon first opening the box and seeing the strap thought: "Dude, this looks stupid. I'm gonna put the camera in my pocket anyway. No way am I going to use this stupid strap!"

Well, the SF Pillow Fight is exactly the place where you will wish you HAD attached the wrist strap to the camera, coz you sure will want to use it. You're gonna be amazed at the awesomeness of the event. It will look like a million people out there just slamming pillows into each other, feathers flying, screams of laughter erupting, and utter chaos all around. Everyone will have a look of pure JOY, like we had when we all were 3 years old. You're gonna think...this is FREAKIN AWESOME! 

Of course you're gonna want to take pics of you, your friends, and all the mayhem. You get your group together, and hold the camera away, pointed towards you all (you know...coz you can't NOT be in the picture that you're taking). You hold down the button, see the red-eye flash flicker a few times, and WHACK! That's right...someone has just smacked your camera with a pillow and it  has flown off into the crowd. You yell....everyone is yelling. You scream....everyone is screaming. You run after it....everyone is running everywhere. And after 20 minutes of running around, getting hit by stray pillows, looking on the ground between people's feet, you find it kicked over to the corner of the plaza, shattered into pieces. 

Don't you wish you had used the wrist strap?
author: Samir P.

description:
Headed over with my homies and dragged them all to the center of the fight and right at 6PM, we turned on each other... and that was the last I saw of them for the next 30 minutes. What a Valentine's Day it was! A chaotic blend of laughs, cries, giggles, guffaws, screams, hits, near misses, near hits, races, runs and just plain fun.

It was a great way to let off steam, get a really good workout (try laughing, hitting someone with a pillow, ducking, defending, avoid getting hit by a pillow, running, finding your way, taking a breath, side stepping, two stepping and then posing for a camera), and just another different way to celebrate Valentine's Day.

Some notes to point out:
1. Get there on time or you'll be left on the outer perimeter trying to get in
2. If you start at the center of the mass, remember, you're going to get pummeled way more (I enjoyed it!)
3. If you can, get goggles (swimming goggles work) since the minuscule  feathers might irritate the eyes
4. Wear a scarf to cover your mouth or in 15 minutes you'll sound and look like a cat hacking up a fur.. er... feather ball
5. DO NOT wear caps, beanies or hats you love for you will feel the pang of separation
6. Unless you have a camera that has a strap that goes around your neck, watch your camera coz it could get damaged
7. Best place to get video footage is either towards the fountain on the 4th step looking down or right in the crowd (the latter seemed very Blair Witch but with feathers and giggles)
8. BEST ADVICE: have a good time, let loose, hit someone you don't know, hit someone you find cute, hit someone who worked with you before to get even (I did).
9. ONLY WORD OF CAUTION: it is a petri dish of germs especially if there is a bug going around. So be warned, if you're one of them folks who is nervous about catching something other than that cute guy / girl's eye. :B

We called it a night at 7PM and then we dragged our asses to the Market Bar (review below) for a great victory (?) Valentine's Day meal. And every time we'd see folks walk by with pillows, we'd rush out and charge them and have an impromptu fight right outside the restaurant. Don't think the restaurant folks minded since they got more customers in every time we did this.

CEST LA VIE!

However, this event has gotten much larger than in past years so watch out for the no-fun people who just bash left and right with no wanton disregard--it's one reason why the SF govt has been putting the control on this event (and the Bay to Breakers to name) .  I've been hit without a pillow and at times even with a camera so there's a chance for someone to just run amok.  

When the event is on a weeknight the best part is seeing all the corporate people getting out of work and either watching what's going on or just partaking in the whole tomfoolery.  Only in San Francisco.

It's still for kids but with the advent of people wrecking the spirit of the show best to leave them at home (or take them elsewhere safe).   That is a tossup since it's literally an all-ages event.  I don't know if they'll have it again in 2011 but I hope it happens.  Weed out the bad apples and let the people have fun--that's what the pillow fight is about. ;-)  Despite its recent shortcomings, the SF Pillow Fight gets 5 stars from me because it's something fun on what is supposed to be a "romantic" holiday--the dateless people can have something to do, and the couples as well!

Get there early--usually all the fun happens before the clock strikes six--then it's open season. :-)

Only d-bags were the ones who tried to hit me when I didn't have a pillow AND I had a camera and the people who actually tried to stir up a fight.  Extra kudos to the people who tried to clean up during/after the event--which probably help reduce the bill and to keep in the spirit of the leave no trace premise. description:
A thin, flat layer of dirty water, abandoned by its earlier, droplet-shaped companions streaming endlessly from the sky, commingles with the most unlikely of partners underfoot - a surprisingly deep pile of genuine and synthetic feathers of seemingly unknown origin. Focusing any modicum of attention on an area higher than an inch or two off the ground reveals the source of at least one of the materials covering the well-worn asphalt of the beginning of Market Street, which in this case happens to be a close-packed and howling mob of total strangers all laying into each other with varying degrees of force. In the middle of the street. With pillows. 

Previous generations have had a number of definers which are too varied, strange, and otherwise recorded by sources far more knowledgeable than I to attempt to give any kind of summation, but I truly believe that nothing as yet invented can top the flash mob. A group of total strangers gathered together in a commonly-used space to accomplish a small, concrete, and completely discrete goal provides an atmosphere and energy at once intimately related to and yet totally separate from the gatherings of the past, filled with both the terror and promise inherent in any large gathering of people but enhanced by both the anonymity and immediacy afforded by the electronically-inspired medium.  

As far as I can discern, the larger political goal of a giant pillow fight is a repudiation of the consumptionist mores and values which permeate our culture's supposed celebration of intimacy through the vehicle of hitting each other with feather-filled sacks, to emphasize the pure human contact that occurs in such an act and provide an outlet for the unseemly glut of emotions riled up by the mass-media machine in the lead-up to said celebration. However, this has absolutely nothing to do with ducking the trio of large men swinging pillows with more enthusiasm than discretion, making sure to smash your own head-rest into the small girl in front of you with less force than you otherwise might, or attempting to change the course of your latest sally mid-swing as you notice your intended target is wrapped in no less than four expensive-looking cameras and desperately trying to proclaim that he's more interested in documenting the experience for his no-doubt-extensive Twitter audience than actually partaking in it.

What else is there to say? Whether you're lucky enough to be kicking off a romantic evening guaranteed to end in bedroom gymnastics or simply bemoaning that modern society is seemingly designed for couples - all the way down to tax law, for goodness' sake - show up and worship at the Church of Down Feathers (And Suitable Synthetic Products).

description:
V Day 2007:  On this most god-awful of cloying commercial holidays nearly a 1000 San Francisco residents partook in a Valentine's Day Pillow fight at the Embarcadero.  When my coworker invited me I was initially hesitant to go.  It was listed on the Squid List and I had a horrible vision of a hideous seething mass of old 'Burners' with manic panicked hair and striped tights writhing around in an orgiastic frenzy of feathers and dust mites.  The whole thing smacked of SF Burning Man style hedonism.  As it turned out the crowd was more Mission hipster than Burner.  A very slight improvement in my estimation.  And much to my surprise it was really fun!  I brought with me my oldest, saggiest IKEA throw pillow coated with a variety of suspicious looking white stains.  Before your imagination carries you away; I must state that the pillow was from my office couch at work though, not my bed.  Whatever that means. 
 
Anyway, it was very cathartic.  I wouldn't have guessed it but there is no better release for pent up aggression than wildly swinging an old pillow at some strangers head!  I had particular fun aiming for those with dreadlocks and/or annoying sunglasses. Feathers were flying everywhere and the concrete was strewn with the fuzzy innards of decreased pillows.  People were giggling maniacally as they clobbered one another.  After 30 minutes or so my friends and I emerged sweaty and ecstatic. Our hair was fringed in feathers and our throats tickled.  I was happy.  And I wanted a drink to celebrate.  

So the questions that begs to be asked is:  why a pillow fight on Valentine's Day?  Could  it be that the only way that single men and women can relate to each other in this city is to bludgeon one another over the head anonymously in a crowd and then run in the opposite direction - laughing hysterically?  Is it that this syrupy holiday, which never fails to freak out everyone (both single and coupled), creates such mass anxiety and irritation that we must exorcise this pent up angst through pretend fighting?  Or perhaps on the supposed 'day of love', we, as a society, prefer to express our hidden hostility overtly in a frenzy of passionate yet harmless attacks towards random strangers?  Hmmmm....

On to my favorite subject:  the inability of men and women to court and date one another in an even vaguely sane way.  While I enjoyed the pillow fight I cannot help but feel a bit sad that it was one of the most uninhibited and carefree times that I have had around strangers in quite a while.  I didn't meet anyone there, nor was I attempting to, but still it seemed a refreshing moment when men and women could put aside their mutual suspicions of one another and just have fun together in a non contrived, silly way.  Most of the time I feel like I am trapped at a bad junior high school dance where boys and girls eye each other fearfully yet desirously from opposite sides of the room.  Everyone is afraid to take the first move, so no one does.  The music plays on and overall things are quite boring.  

Later Valentine's Day night, after several drinks with friends, I found myself walking home alone, swinging my pillow at whatever struck my fancy and cracking up. Just before my house I found an old chain link fence.  I beat my pillow against it until it split open.  That night I went to bed smiling.

description:
Fun fun fun.  I didn't realize that it goes on for a few hours.  I took breaks when I got a piece of feather stuck in my contact lens, but went back in for more. It was a lot of fun, it was silly getting on the bus and seeing other people with their silly pilows.  At one point, I was thinking, "should I get out and wrap this up?"  Then I thought, "well, what else is more fun right now than whacking people with pillows that I can't do any ol' time?   Nothing"  So I kept on going.  I found myself in the middle of a sea of craziness, and it was kind of like when you go in the ocean and realize you've drifted out too far. . .in the middle is where it gets a little more crazy and at one point I realized I was so much farther in than I realized.  I went back to the outsides because it was getting a little tight and a little more aggressive in there than I liked- I mean, I just thought we might get trampled at one point.  But if you're a little apprehensive, just stick to the outsides of the mob.  It's easier to get out and there's more breathing room.  Next year I might wear something over my mouth, because when the wind blew strongly,  everyone was coughing up feathers.  
  Things like the Pillow Fight are why I love San Francisco.  And if you can't make it right at 6, don't worry, we left around 7 and people were still showing up with their pillows, it was still going strong.

If you decided to take photos, make sure your camera is attached to you somehow, by wrist band or neck band, seriously.  If you are tall, be ready to be whacked, if you are wearing funny stuff (like the Elmo guy this year), be ready to be targeted, boy did I had fun watching someone scream "get Elmo"!  And everyone just start whacking the Elmo guy (and he's TALL)!  If you are wearing a helmet, you're doomed to be hit even more.  Word of advice, do wear some kind of scarf or bandana to cover your nose and mouth!  It gets pretty bad when you are starting to cough out feathers.  Also, do NOT hit anyone without a pillow and holding a camera 'cause you'll be hearing f bombs flying around in addition to flying pillows!

description: Pillow Fight nowadays is far from the fun and frolic of former years. Today, this is the flash mob of irresponsible, self-entitled douchebags everywhere. Having it at the same day, same location, same time, every year, means it's no longer the spontaneous flash mob of yesteryears. It's scheduled and calculated. Sure, some show up for the fun of it, but there's enough malicious folks who show up with loaded pillows (with something other than feathers) and whacking everyone as hard as they can without regards to anyone else's safety, to make it not cool. News flash, people, using an otherwise fun event to be mean to other people is not cool and a really douchey thing to do. The douchiness of that mentality is only eclipsed by the complete disregard for the location and the environment. People come, they have fun, and they don't bother cleaning up after themselves. The obscene amount of debris is left in the plaza and worst yet, washed into the bay by way of storm drains. The city is left with the mess because this was all done without a permit. The cost of clean up will come out of something else in the city's budget, but who cares right? Nobody's gonna take away our right for irresponsible fun. yeah... I wish pillow fight would just die.
